case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. E. D. Sheppard

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 527 of 1961 filed by Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay against assessee E. D. Sheppard.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 527 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 6, 1959, of the High Court at Bombay in Income Tax Reference No. 64 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated July 6, 1959 of Bombay High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 64 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 6, 1959, of the High Court at Bombay in Income Tax Reference No. 64 of 1958.

facts.text: Assessee E. D. Sheppard joined Killick Nixon Company partnership in 1930 as an officer-assistant.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was one of such assistants who joined the firm in 1930. The original contract relating to the assessee's employment was not placed on record.

facts.text: Killick Nixon Company was a partnership firm carrying on business in India, owning mills and managing agencies.

anchor.surface_text: Killick Nixon Company was a partnership firm carrying on business on a fairly large scale in India. It owned various mills and managing agencies of a number of limited companies.

facts.text: Firm employed European officer-assistants on 3-year contracts, renewable if satisfactory, with expectation of partnership.

anchor.surface_text: This partnership firm used to employ officer- assistants mostly Europeans, on the basis of a contract for three years if the services of the assistants, so employed were found satisfactory, extensions were invariably given after every three years on increased salary.

facts.text: Assessee's employment terms same as W. J. Heygate's contract, clause 10 allowed termination with one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: It was undisputed that the terms of employment regarding the assessee were the same as those of the contract with W.J. Heygate. Clause 10 of the said agreement provided that notwithstanding anything contained in it, the firm might terminate the agreement without assigning any reasons after giving the assessee one calendar month's previous notice of its intention so to do.

facts.text: Last renewal of assessee's contract on November 1, 1947 to October 31, 1950, salary Rs. 1,200 per month plus 21% commission on net profits, expected Rs. 50,000 per annum.

anchor.surface_text: On November 1, 1947, was made the last renewal. The terms of this last renewal were the same as those of J. G. Milne, a copy of whose renewed contract was placed on record. This renewal provided for a contract of service from November 1, 1947 to October 31, 1950. Under this contract the assessee was to receive a salary of Rs. 1,200/- per month plus a commission of 21 per cent on the net profits of the partnership.

facts.text: In last quarter of 1947, firm decided to reorganize business, floated Killick Industries Ltd. (public) and Killick Nixon and Company (private) to take over business.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime about the last quarter of the year 1947 the firm decided to re- organise its business and with that end in view two limited companies were floated one was called the Killick Industries Ltd., which was a public limited company, and the other was called Killick Nixon and Company which was a private limited company.

facts.text: Notice dated December 29, 1947 terminated assessee's employment from January 31, 1948 due to changes.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee received a notice from the firm dated December 29, 1947. This notice stated that in view of the changes proposed, the assessee's employment with the firm would terminate as from January 31, 1948.

facts.text: Assessee was 38 years old at termination.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was then about 38 years old.

facts.text: 16 officers including assessee on contract, mostly Europeans, contracts expiring on different dates.

anchor.surface_text: There were in all sixteen officers including the assessee who were employed with the firm on contract terms. With the exception of one, all these sixteen officers were Europeans. The three years contracts expired on different dates depending upon the original date of employment

facts.text: Assessee employed by Killick Industries Ltd. from February 1, 1948 on new terms: increased salary, no commission, similar financial position.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the assessee was concerned it appears that the new company styled Killick Industries Ltd., agreed to take over the services of the assessee on new terms under which his salary was increased but the commission was disallowed, but he was left in more or less the same position financially. The assessee entered the employment of Killick Industries Ltd. on these new terms on February 1, 1948.

facts.text: Partnership transferred assets to new companies, received shares in lieu.

anchor.surface_text: Killick Nixon and Company transferred their assets to the new companies and received shares of the new companies in lieu thereof.

facts.text: Killick Industries Ltd. shares face value Rs.100, quoted at Rs.130.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of shares of Killick Industries Ltd. were put on the Indian market. The shares were of the face value of Rs. 100/- only but were quoted in market at Rs. 130/- per share.

facts.text: All covenanted staff officers given shares of Killick Industries Ltd. free; assessee allotted 1,700 shares face value Rs. 2,21,000.

anchor.surface_text: All the members of the covenanted staff in the partnership firm who were officers, were given shares of Killick Industries Ltd. free of payment. The assessee received an allotment of 1, 700 shares of the face value of Rs. 2,21,000/-

facts.text: Assessee claimed shares as compensation for loss of employment due to premature termination.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee's case was that the shares were given by the partnership to the members of the staff as compensation for loss of employment resulting from premature termination of their services.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer taxed shares value Rs. 2,21,000 as consideration for past services under s.7.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, however, sought to bring the shares of the value of Rs. 2,21,000/- to tax on the footing that the shares were allotted to the assessee in consideration of past services.

facts.text: Letter dated October 1, 1952 from D.R.C. Hartley on behalf of firm stating shares allotted as compensation for loss of employment.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee produced before the Income-tax Officer a letter purporting to be written by one D.R.C. Hartley on October 1 , 1952, on behalf of the firm, in which the assessee was informed that the firm had caused 1,700 shares in Killick Industries Ltd. to be allotted as compensation for loss of employment.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order taxing Rs. 2,21,000.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the order passed by the Income-tax Officer bringing to tax the amount of Rs. 2,21,000/was confirmed.

facts.text: Affidavit dated February 22, 1954 by five out of six partners affirming shares as compensation for loss of employment, not reward for past services.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal the assessee produced an affidavit dated February 22, 1954, sworn by five out of the six partners who constituted the firm in the month of January 1948,  the sixth partner having died in the meanwhile  which affirmed the terms of a memorandum submitted to the Income-tax Officer by Messrs Crawford Bayley Co., on behalf of the assessee.

facts.text: Tribunal members differed; President agreed with judicial member that payment solely for loss of employment.

anchor.surface_text: The two members of the Tribunal differed in their views as to the true character of the payment received by the assessee. ... On a difference between the two members of the Tribunal, the question was referred to the President who agreed with the judicial member and expressed the view that the payment was made to the assessee solely for loss of employment

facts.text: Tribunal referred question: Whether Rs. 2,21,000 value of shares is income assessable under s.7.

anchor.surface_text: The present appellant then moved the Tribunal to refer the following question of law to the High Court Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 2,21,000/-, being the value of the shares received by the assessee free of payment, is income of the assessee and assessable under section 7 of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Bombay High Court (Shah and Desai JJ.) held payment not taxable as salary, capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Shah and Desai, JJ., of the Bombay High Court. ... The High Court said that the sole question which fell to be determined was whether the compensation paid to the assessee was to be regarded as an income receipt or a capital receipt in the hands of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court majority (S.K. Das J. for Das, Kapur, Sarkar JJ.) dismissed appeal, upheld not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court committed no error in answering the question referred to it. For the reasons given above, we have come to the conclusion that there is no substance in this appeal. The appeal is accordingly dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Raghubar Dayal J. dissented, would allow appeal, hold taxable as profit in lieu of salary.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL,J.-I have had the advantage of perusing the majority judgment of my learned brother S. K. Das, J., but regret that I am unable to agree ... The High Court was therefore in error in holding otherwise. I would accordingly allow the appeal with costs
certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Bombay under s. 66-A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal made a reference under s. 66 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

Explanation 2.-A payment due to or received by an assessee from an employer or former employer or from a provident or other fund, is to the extent to which it does number companysist of companytributions by the assessee or interest on such companytributions a profit received in lieu of salary for the purposes of this sub- section, unless the payment is made solely as companypen- sation for loss of employment and number by way of remuneration for past services

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: This Court referred with approval to the observations made by Rowlatt, J., in Chibbett v. Joseph Robinson and Sons  1 , which we have earlier quoted.

anchor.surface_text: The income arising from an employment is taxable as salaries under s. 7 the profits of a business are taxable under s. 10 while the income arising from an office which does number involve employment would be taxable under s. 10 as business profits
or in other cases, e. g. an ordinarY director of a companypany, it would be taxable under s. 12 as income from other sources.

issues.text: whether the word 'compensation' in Explanation 2 to section 7 means what is payable or compellable at law as compensation

anchor.surface_text: His first contention is that the word compensation in Explanation 2 means what is payable or compellable at law as compensation, that is, monetary equivalent of the damage suffered consequent on the injury caused.

issues.text: whether under Explanation 2 any payment received by an assessee from his employer or former employer is profit received in lieu of salary unless solely compensation for loss of employment, creating an artificial definition without considering if related to employment or capital/revenue

anchor.surface_text: His second contention is that under the Explanation any payment received by an assessee from his employer or former employer (save payment from a provident or other fund mentioned therein) is profit received in lieu of salary

issues.text: whether the payment was made solely as compensation for loss of employment and not by way of remuneration for past services, or inclusive of compensation for loss of future prospects

anchor.surface_text: Explanation 2.-A payment due to or received by an assessee from an employer or former employer or from a provident or other fund, is to the extent to which it does not consist of contributions by the assessee or interest on such contributions a profit received in lieu of salary

issues.text: whether the payment must be made because of the relation between the employee and the employer to fall within profit received in lieu of salary in Explanation 2

anchor.surface_text: It is true that by the Explanation a payment which is due to or received by an assessee from an employer or a former employer is to be regarded as profit received in lieu of salary for the purposes of sub-section (1) of Section 7 but in our judgment the payment must be made because of the relation between the employee and the employer.

arguments.claim: The word 'compensation' in Explanation 2 to s.7 means what is payable or compellable at law as compensation, i.e., monetary equivalent of damage suffered; assessee suffered no such injury, payment not solely for loss of employment

anchor.surface_text: His first contention is that the word compensation in Explanation 2 means what is payable or compellable at law as compensation, that is, monetary equivalent of the damage suffered consequent on the injury caused. He has submitted that the assessee in this case suffered no injury for which the partnership was compellable at law to pay any damages.

arguments.claim: Under Explanation 2, any payment from employer/former employer (except provident fund) is deemed profit in lieu of salary unless solely compensation for loss of employment; creates artificial definition ignoring capital/revenue or relation to employment

anchor.surface_text: The High Court referred to Explanation 2 to s. 7 (1) of the Income-tax Act, as it stood at the relevant time, and held that if by an agreement between the assessee and his employer, a certain amount was estimated as compensation for the loss likely to be suffered by the assessee by reason of termination of his employment with the firm and was paid to him, the circumstance that the assessee did not in fact suffer any loss by reason of securing another employment would not, for income-tax purposes, alter the nature of the payment made.

arguments.claim: Expectations/prospects rooted in employment; hard to distinguish from loss of employment itself

anchor.surface_text: With reference to Explanation 2 of sub-s.(1) of s.7 an argument was advanced before the High Court to the effect that the payment made to the assessee was not stated to have been made solely for loss of employment but as inclusive of compensation for loss of future prospects. The High Court met this argument by stating that the expectations or prospects were rooted in the employment and it would be difficult to distinguish between compensation for loss of employment and compensation for loss of prospects in that employment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s held that the companymunication of March 1948, companystituted a numberice terminating the services of the assessee as required by the companytract

arguments.claim: Payment not solely compensation as no legal loss (terminable contract); true nature profit for past services despite parties' intention

anchor.surface_text: It follows that if an employee, by the terms of his employment, is not entitled to any relief on the termination of his service in accordance with the terms of the contract, there can arise no occasion for his claiming any compensation for the loss of employment or his being paid any compensation for any loss of employment.

holdings.text: The word 'compensation' in Explanation 2 to section 7(1) does not mean compensation which is payable or compellable at law; it includes voluntary payments or solatium for loss of employment.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these decisions we must over-rule the first contention urged on behalf of the appellant that compensation in Explanation 2 to s. 7(1) means compensation which is payable or compellable at law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on precedents like Henry v. Foster, Chibbett v. Joseph Robinson, Shaw Wallace, Guff v. CIT, Vazir Sultan; compensation focuses on payer's intent to compensate deprivation, not legal liability.

holdings.text: Under Explanation 2 to section 7(1), not every payment from an employer or former employer is deemed profit in lieu of salary; the payment must be made because of the employer-employee relation, and is excluded if solely compensation for loss of employment.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the proposition put in the very wide form in which learned counsel for the department has put it, can be accepted as correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Mahesh Anantrai Pattani (gift not under Expl2); distinguishes artificial deeming; aligns with capital/revenue distinction; payment must relate to service relation.

holdings.text: The payment of Rs. 2,21,000/- (shares) was made solely as compensation for loss of employment and not by way of remuneration for past services, hence not assessable as profit in lieu of salary under section 7.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the payment in the present case was a payment made solely as compensation for loss of employment, there is an end of the appeal because Explanation 2 in clear terms excepts such payment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Tribunal's factual finding based on affidavit/letter evidence; no material to disbelieve; new employment immaterial; HC evidence acceptance binding.

holdings.text: There is no distinction between compensation for loss of employment and compensation for loss of future prospects or expectations rooted in that employment; both qualify under Explanation 2.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court met this argument by stating that the expectations or prospects were rooted in the employment and it would be difficult to distinguish between compensation for loss of employment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses HC view; prospects inseparable from employment source; applies general principle that such payments are capital.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 2,21,000/- is a capital receipt, not income assessable under section 7 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court committed no error in answering the question referred to it. For the reasons given above, we have come to the conclusion that there is no substance in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Expl2 exception; upholds Tribunal/HC; rejects departmental contentions via precedents.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings resolve referred question in assessee's favor.

holdings.text: Compensation for loss of employment requires legal entitlement or compellability; voluntary payments without loss or claim are not compensation but profit in lieu of salary (dissenting view).

anchor.surface_text: It follows that if an employee, by the terms of his employment, is not entitled to any relief on the termination of his service in accordance with the terms of the contract, there can arise no occasion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'compensation' narrowly per Romer LJ in Henry v Foster; distinguishes precedents; requires actual loss/claim.

holdings.text: The payment falls within Explanation 2 as profit in lieu of salary since related to past service and employer-employee relation, even if not legally compellable (dissenting).

anchor.surface_text: Even if such a restricted construction be put on the language of the aforesaid Explanation, that will not take the sum of Rs. 2,21,000/- out of its scope. This sum was paid to the assessee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment proximate to termination, to employee by employer, related to service; deems revenue despite intention.

precedents.cited_proposition: Compensation for loss or cessation of agencies is not income if solatium for compulsory cessation.
precedents.cited_holding: Sums received as compensation for loss of oil agencies were capital, not income.

anchor.surface_text: 1 1957 31 I.T.R. 826. date when the numberice was given. The High Court dealt with this argument and repelled it. Chagla, C. J., who delivered the judgment of the companyrt referred to the decisions in Shaw, Wallace and Company v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 and Chibbett v. Joseph Robinson Sons 2 and then said We are, therefore, of the opinion that the expression companypensation for loss of employ- ment used in explanation 2 to section 7 refers to any payment made, whether under a legal liability or voluntarily, to companypensate or act as a solatium for the loss of employment suffered by the employee.

precedents.case_name: Guff v. Commissioner of Income tax, Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: Compensation for loss of employment includes voluntary payments or solatium, not requiring legal liability.
precedents.cited_holding: Rs.12,000 paid on closure of department was capital compensation for loss of employment.

anchor.surface_text: 3 1959 Supp. 2 S.C.R 375. cancellation by the companypany. The agency agreement in that case was terminable at the will of the companypany and if the companypany chose to do so, the assessee had numberremedy at law in regard to the same. The argument was that therefore there was numberenforceable agreement between the assessee and the companypany which companyld be made the subject matter of a legal claim for companypensation. This argument was repelled and this Court said that in all such cases one has really to look to the nature of the receipt in the hands of the assessee irrespective of any companysideration as to what was actuating the mind of the other party.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad v. Vazir Sultan and Sons
